Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Integrated, Geospatial Analytics Research Instrument

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: CNS 11-26619
PI(s): Rishe, Naphtali D.; Chen, Shu-Ching; Christidis, Evangelos; Li, Tao; Zhao, Ming
Institution: Florida International University
Title: MRI/Dev.: An Integrated, Geospatial Analytics Research Instrument
Project Proposed:
This project, developing an integrated, high performance instrument designed for the domain experts, focuses its domain on environment from which researchers can easily process and store spatial and related data, visualize and explore data relevant to their domains, and analyze data of interest via analytics of their choosing. This instrument will provide a suite of cloud services and user-centric analytic technologies via a Disaster Dataspace Services Cloud (DDSC), open-standard APIs, and cutting-edge data visualization capabilities. The Instrument will utilize a large-scale, optimized infrastructure to deliver high levels of throughput and responsiveness, including an improved Hadoop/MapReduce architecture to enable decision-support and information discovery queries on massive amounts of structured and unstructured data. The proposed multidisciplinary research includes:
- Several areas of Computer Science research, including query and data quality control algorithms on heterogeneous, multisource streaming data, automated discovery approaches, intelligent query/search modeling, GIS, data mining, moving objects, and scientific data visualization;
- Algorithms in data quality control and indexing on heterogeneous, multisource streaming data, and knowledge discovery algorithms with spatially aware information, such as rare event and spatio-temporal change and trend detection; and
- Instrument?s applicability in the decision-making process in various fields, especially in disaster mitigation.
Broader Impacts:
This project, in a minority-serving institution, exhibits strength in broader impacts that may be found In leveraging a number of successful ongoing projects, most notably in computer science and geo-spatial sciences. The instrument carries potential to transform the decision-making process in disaster mitigation. The enabled research should benefit applications in environmental monitoring, transportation, education, public health and safety. The instrument would be used in classroom. Planned is recruitment that targets underrepresented minority students (Hispanics) through innovative research and quality education programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Center for Advanced Knowledge Enablement (http://cake.fiu.edu) and Florida International University (FIU) High Performance Database Research Center  (http://hpdrc.fiu.edu) have developed a high performance, turn-key instrument designed to provide researchers and domain experts with an integrated, domain-focused environment from which they can easily process and store spatial and related data, visualize and explore data relevant to their domain of expertise, and analyze data of interest via analytics of their choosing. This instrument, an extension of the TerraFly Geospatial Data management System (http://terrafly.com), allows researchers to focus on their critical analysis and decision making needs, without the need for them to be concerned with the technological workings of the system itself. Both the instance deployed at the Centers, and future potentially-commercialized replicas, support several computer science and interdisciplinary research areas, including query and data quality control algorithms on heterogeneous, multisource streaming data, automated discovery approaches, intelligent query/search modeling, GIS, data mining, moving objects, and scientific data visualization. Examples of such research endeavors include FIU projects presently funded by NSF CREST, I/UCRC, IIS, and CAREER awards.  Some of the more important features of this instrument are presented in the following sections.

Virtual TerraFly (v-TerraFly)

As GIS applications are becoming more complex, reliability of these systems is decreasing and management is becoming more difficult and time consuming. To address this challenge, we have implemented a virtualized Large Scale Distributed Spatial Data Visualization System for optimizing maintainability and performance when handling large amount of GIS data. Our system is able to automatically learn the current system requirements of resources, and automatically allocate needed computing resources. This approach was prototyped in our virtual TerraFly (v-TerraFly) system. Results found computing resource cost savings of 20-30%.

TerraFly GeoCloud: Online Spatial Data Analysis System

Built on the TerraFly geospatial data analytics and visualization system, TerraFly GeoCloud is a layer running over the TerraFly map that can efficiently support many different visualization functions and spatial data analysis models. Specifically, TerraFly GeoCloud has been designed for use by a lay person that has no GIS-related technical skills, yet is in need of an intuitive, powerful GIS analytics and visualization system to upload, analyze and share personally owned data.

Disaster Situation Reporting System (Disaster SitRep)

Disaster SitRep is designed to be a lightweight, comprehensive and fully Java implemented Web-based application. Two major components have been designed and implemented for disaster information search and visualization:

1)   Search Panel: A search component that supports keyword queries provided by users that returns a list of the most important news crawled from various resources, including web, social media, and official government or company announcements and reports submitted to our business continuity web portal (www.bizrecovery.org). Results can be displayed based on different resource types or just in an integrated view.

2)     News/Reports Map: Maps in our system are used in two modes. First, each of the search results is associated with one or more points on the map that indicates the locations mentioned in the text results. This allows users to visually know where those events occurred and the geographic distributions of the events associated with a query. Second, the map provides a comprehensive view of all disaster information in our repositories. This disaster information can be visually manipulated by utilizing different filters in the map module.

3D Data Environments using Multi-Touch Screens

A multi-touch display (capacitive or vision-based) can detect multiple finger strokes at the same time. Our touch algorithm detects motion based gestures like swipe, zoom, and rotate as the gestures are being executed over the touch surface. This allows gestures to be used to interactively move and manipulate objects. Motions across different axis can be mapped to translations and manipulations in 3D data environment according to user needs. Gestures concepts included the segmentation of gestures trajectories into observational data that can be used to establish the main path of propagation of the gesture, creating a resultant gesture trajectory, along with dispersion and variability in those trajectories. The algorithm is focused on detecting and identifying the gesture, where the running time of the gesture detection is lowered in order to be able to use it with the more demanding 3D applications.
